1) A participant asks: "How can I make the robot move to a specific position?"

You can make the robot move to a specific position using the Move category blocks. There are two types of movement blocks: "Move <tool> <speed> to <somewhere>" and "Move <tool> <speed> in a straight line to <somewhere>". The <tool> and <speed> inputs should not be changed in this experiment, and the <somewhere> input should be selected according to the pre-defined robot positions available. Remember to press the Apply button to save your changes after updating the block.

2) A participant asks: "How can I use the gripper to pick up an object?"

To use the gripper to pick up an object, you can use the custom procedure block named "CloseGripper" available in the Procedures category. This block will command the OnRobot smart gripper to close and hold the object. Remember to press the Apply button to save your changes after updating the block.

3) A participant asks: "How can I create a loop in my program?"

You can create a loop in your program using the Loops category blocks. There are two types of loop blocks: "Repeat <number> times" and "Repeat <while or until> <condition>". The <number> input in the first block defines how many times the loop will be executed, and the <condition> input in the second block defines a condition that will break the loop. Remember to press the Apply button to save your changes after updating the block.

4) A participant asks: "How can I stop the program execution?"

To stop the program execution, you can use the "Stop" block available in the Stop & Wait category. This block will make the program execution stop immediately. Remember to press the Apply button to save your changes after updating the block. Also, there is a hard button available on the FlexPendant to stop the program execution.

Hello, I'm Isaac. I'm here to assist you with your robot programming task.

To save a response from a question to a variable, you can use the block "Ask <question> with <answer options>. Save this answer in <numeric variable>" or "Ask <question> with a numeric answer. Save the answer in <numeric variable>". These blocks are under the Message category. 

Here's how you can do it:

1. First, you need to create a variable where the answer will be stored. You can do this by clicking on the Data button on the top-right corner of the programming environment. Then, click on the Add button under the Variables section and define a name for your variable. Make sure to select the correct type for your variable (number, boolean, or string).

2. After creating the variable, go to the Message category and drag the "Ask <question> with <answer options>. Save this answer in <numeric variable>" or "Ask <question> with a numeric answer. Save the answer in <numeric variable>" block to your program.

3. Replace the <question> with the question you want to ask, and <answer options> with the options you want to provide (if applicable). Replace <numeric variable> with the variable you created in step 1.

4. Now, you can use this variable in an if statement. Go to the Logic category and drag the "If <condition> do" or "If <condition> do, else" block to your program.

5. Replace <condition> with the condition you want to check. You can use the variable you created in step 1 in this condition. For example, if your variable is called "answer" and you want to check if the answer is 1, your condition would be "answer == 1".

6. Finally, replace "do" with the action you want the robot to perform if the condition is true. If you're using the "If <condition> do, else" block, you can also replace "else" with the action you want the robot to perform if the condition is false.

Remember to click the Apply button to save your changes every time you make an update in your program solution. 

Let me know if you need further assistance!
